He told Mole all about the fun they would have on the open road. He made it sound like the best thing in the world. Mole got so excited that he could hardly sit still in his chair. In the end, Rat let Toad and Mole change his mind. He did not want to disappoint his friends. So after lunch, they loaded up the wagon and set off on their adventure.

---

It was a beautiful golden afternoon. The dust from the road smelled rich and good. Birds sang to them from the thick fruit trees on both sides of the road. Other travelers called out "Good day!" to them. Some people stopped to say nice things about their beautiful wagon."Ah," said Toad, stretching out his legs. "This is the real life for a gentleman!" They had a pleasant trip along the narrow country roads. Everything was going well until they reached the big highway. That is where disaster struck them.

---

They were walking along the highway when they saw a small cloud of dust. It was coming toward them very fast. From the dust cloud, they heard a faint "toot-toot!" It sounded like an animal in pain. They turned to keep talking to each other. But in just one moment, everything changed completely. With a big blast of wind and a whirl of loud sound, it was right on top of them! They had to jump into the nearest ditch to get out of the way.

---

The horn of the motor car rang out loudly, "TOOT-TOOT!" They got a quick look inside the car. It had shiny glass and beautiful leather seats. Then the amazing motor car threw a huge cloud of dust that made it hard for them to see. The car got smaller and smaller as it drove away into the distance.The old grey horse got scared and jumped forward. Then there was a terrible crash. Their beautiful yellow wagon fell over on its side in the ditch. Rat was very angry. He danced up and down in the road. "You bad people!" he shouted, shaking both fists in the air. "You mean drivers! You road hogs! I will call the police on you! I will report you for this!"
question: What lesson can readers learn from how the friends' pleasant trip suddenly changed?
option_1: Good times can end quickly.
option_2: Friends always help each other.
option_3: Horses need careful training.
option_4: Wagons break very easily.
option_1_explanation: You got it! The story shows how "everything changed completely" in just one moment. Their fun trip turned into disaster very quickly.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The friends do travel together, but the story doesn't show them helping each other when trouble happens.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story isn't about training horses. It's about how their good day suddenly turned bad.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the wagon didn't break because it was weak. The story shows how fast things can change from good to bad.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 2 transition point, analyzing thematic significance of setting change - differs from reference which focuses on specific character motivation. This variant requires understanding how location shift signals thematic meaning.
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential story messages or lessons
specificity_check: all state interpretations of story meaning
length_check: A=8 words, B=10 words, C=9 words, D=9 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: no synonyms; each presents distinct thematic interpretations
single_correct_check: only A is defensible given the highway/motor car connection
diversity_check: targets paragraph 2 transition and thematic meaning - completely different analytical focus from reference
original_question: The passage describes the friends' journey as going well 'until they reached the big highway.' What does this detail suggest about the story's message?

passage_text:
The Open Road, Part IV
    
    
        Where was Toad? He was sitting in the middle of the dusty road. He stared at the motor car as it drove away. Toad went into a kind of dream. His face looked calm and peaceful. He said quietly, "toot-toot!" Rat shook him by the shoulder, but Toad did not move at all."What a beautiful sight!" Toad said softly. "That is the REAL way to travel! The ONLY way to travel! Oh my! Oh my! I must get one!" Mole tapped Rat on the shoulder, but Toad kept talking."I can't believe I never KNEW about this!" he said. "All those years are wasted now. I never knew about motor cars. I never even dreamed about them! But NOW I know. Oh, what fun I will have! What dust clouds will form behind me when I speed down the road! What wagons I will push into the ditch! Those awful little wagons, common wagons, yellow-colored wagons!"

---

"What should we do with him?" asked Mole. "There is nothing we can do," said Rat. "He has gone mad. He has got a new idea stuck in his head. It is always like this when he starts something new. He will go on like that for days now. He will walk around in a happy dream. He won't be able to do anything useful. Never mind him. Let's go see what we can do about the wagon."They looked at the wagon carefully. They found that it would not work anymore. One wheel had been broken into many pieces. "Come on!" said Rat. "We will have to walk. It is five or six miles to the nearest town. The sooner we start walking, the better.""But what about Toad?" asked Mole. "We can't leave him here sitting in the middle of the road by himself! It's not safe. What if another motor car comes along?" "Never mind him," said Rat. "I'm done with him!"

---

They had not walked very far when they heard footsteps behind them. Toad caught up with them. He put his paw inside each of their arms. "Now, look here Toad!" said Rat in a sharp voice. "As soon as we get to the town, you must go straight to the police station. You must see if they know anything about that motor car. You must find out who owns it. You must complain because your wagon is broken. Then, you must go to a blacksmith so he can fix the wagon. Meanwhile, Mole and I will find rooms where we can stay until the wagon is ready.""Police station? Complain?" said Toad in a dreamy voice. "Why would I complain about that beautiful motor car? I am done with wagons forever. I never want to see that wagon again or hear about it. Oh, Ratty!" The animals spent the night in town. The next day, Rat and Mole made their way back to the river bank.

---

A few days later, Mole was sitting on the bank fishing. Rat walked up to him. "Have you heard the news?" Rat asked. "Everyone is talking about it. Toad went to town on the train this morning. He has ordered a large and very expensive motor car."
question: Based on what happened in the story, where should Rat and Mole look the next time they want to find Toad?
option_1: sitting in the middle of the road
option_2: at a motor car dealer in town
option_3: walking along the river bank
option_4: at the police station complaining
option_1_explanation: Good try! Toad was sitting in the road at first, but that's not where he'd be later. The story shows Toad got excited about cars and would go buy one.
option_2_explanation: Great job! You figured out that Toad loves motor cars and would go buy one. He said "I must get one!" so he'd be at a car dealer.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but Rat and Mole went to the river, not Toad. Toad was excited about "motor cars" and would go get one in town.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Toad doesn't want to complain about anything. He said "I must get one!" about motor cars, so he'd go buy one instead.

Meanwhile, Mole and I will find rooms where we can stay until the wagon is ready.""Police station? Complain?" said Toad in a dreamy voice. "Why would I complain about that beautiful motor car? I am done with wagons forever. I never want to see that wagon again or hear about it. Oh, Ratty!" The animals spent the night in town. The next day, Rat and Mole made their way back to the river bank.

---

passage_text:
The Open Road, Part IV
    
    
        Where was Toad? He was sitting in the middle of the dusty road. He stared at the motor car as it drove away. Toad went into a kind of dream. His face looked calm and peaceful. He said quietly, "toot-toot!" Rat shook him by the shoulder, but Toad did not move at all."What a beautiful sight!" Toad said softly. "That is the REAL way to travel! The ONLY way to travel! Oh my! Oh my! I must get one!" Mole tapped Rat on the shoulder, but Toad kept talking."I can't believe I never KNEW about this!" he said. "All those years are wasted now. I never knew about motor cars. I never even dreamed about them! But NOW I know. Oh, what fun I will have! What dust clouds will form behind me when I speed down the road! What wagons I will push into the ditch! Those awful little wagons, common wagons, yellow-colored wagons!"

---

"What should we do with him?" asked Mole. "There is nothing we can do," said Rat. "He has gone mad. He has got a new idea stuck in his head. It is always like this when he starts something new. He will go on like that for days now. He will walk around in a happy dream. He won't be able to do anything useful. Never mind him. Let's go see what we can do about the wagon."They looked at the wagon carefully. They found that it would not work anymore. One wheel had been broken into many pieces. "Come on!" said Rat. "We will have to walk. It is five or six miles to the nearest town. The sooner we start walking, the better.""But what about Toad?" asked Mole. "We can't leave him here sitting in the middle of the road by himself! It's not safe. What if another motor car comes along?" "Never mind him," said Rat. "I'm done with him!"

---

They had not walked very far when they heard footsteps behind them. Toad caught up with them. He put his paw inside each of their arms. "Now, look here Toad!" said Rat in a sharp voice. "As soon as we get to the town, you must go straight to the police station. You must see if they know anything about that motor car. You must find out who owns it. You must complain because your wagon is broken. Then, you must go to a blacksmith so he can fix the wagon. Meanwhile, Mole and I will find rooms where we can stay until the wagon is ready.""Police station? Complain?" said Toad in a dreamy voice. "Why would I complain about that beautiful motor car? I am done with wagons forever. I never want to see that wagon again or hear about it. Oh, Ratty!" The animals spent the night in town. The next day, Rat and Mole made their way back to the river bank.

---

A few days later, Mole was sitting on the bank fishing. Rat walked up to him. "Have you heard the news?" Rat asked. "Everyone is talking about it. Toad went to town on the train this morning. He has ordered a large and very expensive motor car."
question: How did Mole show concern for Toad's safety when they prepared to leave?
option_1: He suggested they carry Toad to town on their shoulders.
option_2: He asked what they should do about leaving Toad in the road where another motor car might come.
option_3: He offered to stay behind with Toad while Rat went for help.
option_4: He tried to wake Toad up by shaking him repeatedly.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Mole never said they should carry Toad. He was worried about leaving Toad in the road, but didn't suggest carrying him.
option_2_explanation: You got it! Mole asked "what about Toad?" because he was worried about leaving him sitting in the dangerous road. He cared about Toad's safety!
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but Mole didn't offer to stay behind with Toad. He asked what they should do about leaving Toad alone in the road.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! It was Rat who shook Toad earlier, not Mole. Mole showed concern later when they planned to walk away.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 2-3 focusing on Mole's specific dialogue expressing safety concerns - differs from reference which asks about future locations.
homogeneity_check: all choices are ways of showing concern/helping
specificity_check: all describe specific helpful actions at similar detail
length_check: A:11 words, B:18 words, C:12 words, D:9 words - balanced within 100% range
semantic_distance_check: each describes different methods of showing concern
single_correct_check: only B matches Mole's actual dialogue and actions
diversity_check: targets paragraphs 2-3 character dialogue - completely different from reference about future prediction

passage_text:
The Open Road, Part IV
    
    
        Where was Toad? He was sitting in the middle of the dusty road. He stared at the motor car as it drove away. Toad went into a kind of dream. His face looked calm and peaceful. He said quietly, "toot-toot!" Rat shook him by the shoulder, but Toad did not move at all."What a beautiful sight!" Toad said softly. "That is the REAL way to travel! The ONLY way to travel! Oh my! Oh my! I must get one!" Mole tapped Rat on the shoulder, but Toad kept talking."I can't believe I never KNEW about this!" he said. "All those years are wasted now. I never knew about motor cars. I never even dreamed about them! But NOW I know. Oh, what fun I will have! What dust clouds will form behind me when I speed down the road! What wagons I will push into the ditch! Those awful little wagons, common wagons, yellow-colored wagons!"

---

"What should we do with him?" asked Mole. "There is nothing we can do," said Rat. "He has gone mad. He has got a new idea stuck in his head. It is always like this when he starts something new. He will go on like that for days now. He will walk around in a happy dream. He won't be able to do anything useful. Never mind him. Let's go see what we can do about the wagon."They looked at the wagon carefully. They found that it would not work anymore. One wheel had been broken into many pieces. "Come on!" said Rat. "We will have to walk. It is five or six miles to the nearest town. The sooner we start walking, the better.""But what about Toad?" asked Mole. "We can't leave him here sitting in the middle of the road by himself! It's not safe. What if another motor car comes along?" "Never mind him," said Rat. "I'm done with him!"

---

They had not walked very far when they heard footsteps behind them. Toad caught up with them. He put his paw inside each of their arms. "Now, look here Toad!" said Rat in a sharp voice. "As soon as we get to the town, you must go straight to the police station. You must see if they know anything about that motor car. You must find out who owns it. You must complain because your wagon is broken. Then, you must go to a blacksmith so he can fix the wagon. Meanwhile, Mole and I will find rooms where we can stay until the wagon is ready.""Police station? Complain?" said Toad in a dreamy voice. "Why would I complain about that beautiful motor car? I am done with wagons forever. I never want to see that wagon again or hear about it. Oh, Ratty!" The animals spent the night in town. The next day, Rat and Mole made their way back to the river bank.

---

A few days later, Mole was sitting on the bank fishing. Rat walked up to him. "Have you heard the news?" Rat asked. "Everyone is talking about it. Toad went to town on the train this morning. He has ordered a large and very expensive motor car."
question: What is the main idea of this story about Toad?
option_1: fixing a broken wagon
option_2: becoming excited about motor cars
option_3: walking to the nearest town
option_4: spending the night away from home
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story mentions a broken wagon, but that's not what Toad cares about. Toad gets excited about motor cars and says "I must get one!"
option_2_explanation: Great job! You found the main idea by noticing Toad's excitement about motor cars. He says "I must get one!" and can't stop talking about them.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but walking to town is what Rat and Mole plan to do. The story is really about how Toad gets excited and says "I must get one!" about motor cars.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Spending the night away happens to all the animals, but it's not the main idea. Toad's big change is getting excited about motor cars.

option_1: The narrator admires Toad's enthusiasm and thinks motor cars are wonderful.
option_2: The narrator presents Toad's behavior as excessive and unreasonable.
option_3: The narrator believes Toad is making a wise and careful decision.
option_4: The narrator shows that Toad's excitement is shared by all his friends.

passage_text:
The Open Road, Part IV
    
    
        Where was Toad? He was sitting in the middle of the dusty road. He stared at the motor car as it drove away. Toad went into a kind of dream. His face looked calm and peaceful. He said quietly, "toot-toot!" Rat shook him by the shoulder, but Toad did not move at all."What a beautiful sight!" Toad said softly. "That is the REAL way to travel! The ONLY way to travel! Oh my! Oh my! I must get one!" Mole tapped Rat on the shoulder, but Toad kept talking."I can't believe I never KNEW about this!" he said. "All those years are wasted now. I never knew about motor cars. I never even dreamed about them! But NOW I know. Oh, what fun I will have! What dust clouds will form behind me when I speed down the road! What wagons I will push into the ditch! Those awful little wagons, common wagons, yellow-colored wagons!"

---

"What should we do with him?" asked Mole. "There is nothing we can do," said Rat. "He has gone mad. He has got a new idea stuck in his head. It is always like this when he starts something new. He will go on like that for days now. He will walk around in a happy dream. He won't be able to do anything useful. Never mind him. Let's go see what we can do about the wagon."They looked at the wagon carefully. They found that it would not work anymore. One wheel had been broken into many pieces. "Come on!" said Rat. "We will have to walk. It is five or six miles to the nearest town. The sooner we start walking, the better.""But what about Toad?" asked Mole. "We can't leave him here sitting in the middle of the road by himself! It's not safe. What if another motor car comes along?" "Never mind him," said Rat. "I'm done with him!"

---

They had not walked very far when they heard footsteps behind them. Toad caught up with them. He put his paw inside each of their arms. "Now, look here Toad!" said Rat in a sharp voice. "As soon as we get to the town, you must go straight to the police station. You must see if they know anything about that motor car. You must find out who owns it. You must complain because your wagon is broken. Then, you must go to a blacksmith so he can fix the wagon. Meanwhile, Mole and I will find rooms where we can stay until the wagon is ready.""Police station? Complain?" said Toad in a dreamy voice. "Why would I complain about that beautiful motor car? I am done with wagons forever. I never want to see that wagon again or hear about it. Oh, Ratty!" The animals spent the night in town. The next day, Rat and Mole made their way back to the river bank.

---

A few days later, Mole was sitting on the bank fishing. Rat walked up to him. "Have you heard the news?" Rat asked. "Everyone is talking about it. Toad went to town on the train this morning. He has ordered a large and very expensive motor car."
question: In the story, why does Toad's attitude create a problem that Rat cannot solve?
option_1: Toad refuses to listen to practical advice because he is completely focused on his new interest.
option_2: Toad wants to walk to town faster than Rat can keep up with him.
option_3: Toad insists on driving the motor car that broke their wagon.
option_4: Toad demands that Rat buy a motor car too before helping with repairs.
option_1_explanation: Exactly! Rat says Toad has "gone mad" and won't listen to helpful ideas. Toad only cares about getting his own motor car.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say Toad walks too fast. The problem is that Toad won't pay attention to Rat's helpful ideas.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Toad doesn't want to drive that same car. He wants to buy his own motor car instead.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Toad never asks Rat to buy anything. Toad only talks about getting his own motor car.
differentiation_notes: Targets cause-effect analysis of why character conflict cannot be resolved in paragraphs 2-3 - differs from reference which asks about contrasting character viewpoints.
homogeneity_check: all choices are reasons why Toad's attitude creates unsolvable problems
specificity_check: all describe problem-creating behaviors at similar detail
length_check: A:16 words, B:13 words, C:11 words, D:12 words - balanced within 45% range
semantic_distance_check: each describes distinctly different problematic behaviors
single_correct_check: only A identifies the core conflict shown in their dialogue
diversity_check: targets conflict resolution analysis - different from reference about viewpoint comparison

passage_text:
The Open Road, Part IV
    
    
        Where was Toad? He was sitting in the middle of the dusty road. He stared at the motor car as it drove away. Toad went into a kind of dream. His face looked calm and peaceful. He said quietly, "toot-toot!" Rat shook him by the shoulder, but Toad did not move at all."What a beautiful sight!" Toad said softly. "That is the REAL way to travel! The ONLY way to travel! Oh my! Oh my! I must get one!" Mole tapped Rat on the shoulder, but Toad kept talking."I can't believe I never KNEW about this!" he said. "All those years are wasted now. I never knew about motor cars. I never even dreamed about them! But NOW I know. Oh, what fun I will have! What dust clouds will form behind me when I speed down the road! What wagons I will push into the ditch! Those awful little wagons, common wagons, yellow-colored wagons!"

---

"What should we do with him?" asked Mole. "There is nothing we can do," said Rat. "He has gone mad. He has got a new idea stuck in his head. It is always like this when he starts something new. He will go on like that for days now. He will walk around in a happy dream. He won't be able to do anything useful. Never mind him. Let's go see what we can do about the wagon."They looked at the wagon carefully. They found that it would not work anymore. One wheel had been broken into many pieces. "Come on!" said Rat. "We will have to walk. It is five or six miles to the nearest town. The sooner we start walking, the better.""But what about Toad?" asked Mole. "We can't leave him here sitting in the middle of the road by himself! It's not safe. What if another motor car comes along?" "Never mind him," said Rat. "I'm done with him!"

---

They had not walked very far when they heard footsteps behind them. Toad caught up with them. He put his paw inside each of their arms. "Now, look here Toad!" said Rat in a sharp voice. "As soon as we get to the town, you must go straight to the police station. You must see if they know anything about that motor car. You must find out who owns it. You must complain because your wagon is broken. Then, you must go to a blacksmith so he can fix the wagon. Meanwhile, Mole and I will find rooms where we can stay until the wagon is ready.""Police station? Complain?" said Toad in a dreamy voice. "Why would I complain about that beautiful motor car? I am done with wagons forever. I never want to see that wagon again or hear about it. Oh, Ratty!" The animals spent the night in town. The next day, Rat and Mole made their way back to the river bank.

---

A few days later, Mole was sitting on the bank fishing. Rat walked up to him. "Have you heard the news?" Rat asked. "Everyone is talking about it. Toad went to town on the train this morning. He has ordered a large and very expensive motor car."
question: When Rat says he is 'done with' Toad, what does this reveal about how Rat views the future of their friendship?
option_1: Rat believes their friendship will become stronger once Toad gets the motor car he wants.
option_2: Rat feels frustrated and likely plans to distance himself from Toad for a while.
option_3: Rat thinks they should work together to buy a motor car they can share.
option_4: Rat expects Toad will apologize and change his behavior immediately.
option_1_explanation: Good try! When Rat says he's done with Toad, he sounds angry and fed up, not happy. He doesn't think the motor car will make things better.
option_2_explanation: You got it! Rat says "There is nothing we can do" and sounds really frustrated with Toad. When someone says they're done, it means they want space.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but Rat doesn't want a motor car at all! He's upset because Toad wants one, not because he wants to share it.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Rat says Toad "will go on like that for days now." This means Rat thinks Toad will keep acting crazy, not say sorry.
differentiation_notes: Targets interpretation of specific phrase to predict future relationship trajectory in paragraph 2 - differs from reference which asks about contrasting independent future actions.
homogeneity_check: all choices are predictions about the friendship's future
specificity_check: all describe future relationship scenarios at similar detail
length_check: A:15 words, B:13 words, C:13 words, D:10 words - balanced within 50% range
semantic_distance_check: each predicts distinctly different friendship outcomes
single_correct_check: only B correctly interprets the idiom 'done with' and supporting context
diversity_check: targets relationship prediction from specific phrase analysis - different from reference about contrasting character actions

passage_text:
Classifying Living Things
    
    
        Hello! Rattenborough here! I am back to help you learn about living things. Do you remember me? I study animals and plants. Today we will learn how scientists sort living things into groups. This sorting is called classifying. Let me ask you something important. How do you know if something is alive or not alive?
All living things have special things about them. These special things are called characteristics. Here are the main characteristics all living things have. All living things make energy from food. All living things can have babies or make more living things like themselves. All living things have a life cycle. This means they start small and then grow big. All living things can adapt. This means they change to fit better in their home.

---

Plants are one big group of living things. Plants have all the same characteristics as other living things. Plants make energy from food, but they make their own food! They use the sun, water, and air to make food. Plants make seeds that become new plants. Plants grow from tiny seeds into small plants and then become adult plants. Plants can adapt to their habitat. A habitat is the place where something lives. For example, a cactus lives in a dry desert. It does not need as much water as other plants.
Animals are living things too! Animal groups come in all shapes and sizes. Animals get energy from the food they eat. Animals can have babies. Baby animals start small but grow into adult animals. Animals can adapt to their habitat too. Polar bears have white fur so they can hide in the snow where they live.

---

Plants and animals are both living things, but they are different in important ways. For example, animals move from place to place, but plants stay in one spot. Scientists study how living things are the same and different. Then they sort or classify them into big groups called kingdoms. There are five kingdom groups of living things. You just learned about two of them. These are the plant kingdom and the animal kingdom.
Scientists study animals in the animal kingdom. They classify them by looking at what makes them the same. One way scientists sort animals is by checking if they have a backbone. Insects do not have backbones, but birds and fish do. So animals with backbones go in different groups. Insects make up the biggest group in the animal kingdom. But there are other big groups like birds and fish too.

---

We classify things around us so we can know our world better. As we learn about living things, we also learn about ourselves. So far, scientists have found over 1 million different kinds of animals. Most of these are insects! Many scientists think there may be close to 10 million other animals that we have not found yet!
That's all for now! Rattenborough, over and out! I will be back in the next chapter to tell you more about how animals are sorted into different groups.
question: In section 2, the word 'adapt' means
option_1: make more babies
option_2: move to a new place
option_3: change to fit better
option_4: grow very large
option_1_explanation: Good try! Having babies and adapting are two different things in the story. The text says "adapt means they change to fit better."
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but adapt doesn't mean moving somewhere new. The story says "adapt means they change to fit better in their home."
option_3_explanation: Great job! You found the meaning right in the story. The text says "adapt means they change to fit better."
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Growing big is part of life cycle, not adapting. The story says "adapt means they change to fit better."

option_3: to persuade readers that insects are the most important animals
option_4: to describe which living things are found in different habitats

passage_text:
Classifying Living Things
    
    
        Hello! Rattenborough here! I am back to help you learn about living things. Do you remember me? I study animals and plants. Today we will learn how scientists sort living things into groups. This sorting is called classifying. Let me ask you something important. How do you know if something is alive or not alive?
All living things have special things about them. These special things are called characteristics. Here are the main characteristics all living things have. All living things make energy from food. All living things can have babies or make more living things like themselves. All living things have a life cycle. This means they start small and then grow big. All living things can adapt. This means they change to fit better in their home.

---

Plants are one big group of living things. Plants have all the same characteristics as other living things. Plants make energy from food, but they make their own food! They use the sun, water, and air to make food. Plants make seeds that become new plants. Plants grow from tiny seeds into small plants and then become adult plants. Plants can adapt to their habitat. A habitat is the place where something lives. For example, a cactus lives in a dry desert. It does not need as much water as other plants.
Animals are living things too! Animal groups come in all shapes and sizes. Animals get energy from the food they eat. Animals can have babies. Baby animals start small but grow into adult animals. Animals can adapt to their habitat too. Polar bears have white fur so they can hide in the snow where they live.

---

Plants and animals are both living things, but they are different in important ways. For example, animals move from place to place, but plants stay in one spot. Scientists study how living things are the same and different. Then they sort or classify them into big groups called kingdoms. There are five kingdom groups of living things. You just learned about two of them. These are the plant kingdom and the animal kingdom.
Scientists study animals in the animal kingdom. They classify them by looking at what makes them the same. One way scientists sort animals is by checking if they have a backbone. Insects do not have backbones, but birds and fish do. So animals with backbones go in different groups. Insects make up the biggest group in the animal kingdom. But there are other big groups like birds and fish too.

---

We classify things around us so we can know our world better. As we learn about living things, we also learn about ourselves. So far, scientists have found over 1 million different kinds of animals. Most of these are insects! Many scientists think there may be close to 10 million other animals that we have not found yet!
That's all for now! Rattenborough, over and out! I will be back in the next chapter to tell you more about how animals are sorted into different groups.
question: Based on the entire passage, what main idea does the author want readers to understand about studying living things?
option_1: Scientists study living things by organizing them into systems
option_2: Plants and animals need different types of food to survive
option_3: Most living things on Earth are insects that live everywhere
option_4: Living things must have backbones to be in the animal kingdom

option_2_explanation: Good try! The story does mention food, but that's just one small part. The main idea is about how scientists sort and group living things together.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Insects are mentioned at the end, but the whole story is about classifying living things. Look for what Rattenborough talks about most.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but backbones are just one example of sorting animals. The main idea is about how scientists classify all living things into groups.

specificity_check: all at similar level making claims about key concepts
length_check: 8-11 words each, balanced within 10%

passage_text:
Warm-Blooded and Cold-Blooded Animals
    
    
        Hello! Rattenborough here again! In the last chapter, you learned how scientists put living things into groups called kingdoms. You learned about animals and plants. You also learned that animals get put into smaller groups too.
Today, you will learn more about the animal kingdom. There are many kinds of animals that are different from each other. Scientists look at these differences to put animals into groups.

---

Many animals like cats, mice, rats, cows, elephants, tigers, and even people belong to a group called mammals. So you and I are mammals! All mammals have hair, but some have more hair than others. You have to get very close to an elephant to see its hair, but it is still a mammal. Another thing about mammals is that they give birth to live babies. Mammal babies start breathing, moving, and looking for food right when they are born. Mammal mothers make milk to feed their babies. This is a very important thing that all mammals do.
Do you think a crocodile is a mammal? The answer is no! Here's why. Crocodiles have hard scales, not hair or fur. Crocodiles lay eggs and baby crocodiles come out of those eggs. A baby crocodile does not get milk from its mother. Its first meal might be a bug. Later, it will eat bigger animals.
Crocodiles belong to a different group of animals called reptiles. Snakes, lizards, and turtles are reptiles too.

---

Scientists also put animals into groups based on how they control their body temperature. All animals need to keep a constant temperature inside their bodies. This means the temperature stays the same. If an animal gets too hot or too cold, its body will not work right. The animal may get sick or even die.
Mammals are warm-blooded animals. When warm-blooded animals are in a cold place, they use energy from food to keep their bodies warm. Some warm-blooded animals shiver to stay warm. When they shiver, their bodies make heat.
When warm-blooded animals are somewhere hot, their bodies work differently to cool off. Some warm-blooded animals, like people, sweat to stay cool. Dogs pant to stay cool. Other warm-blooded animals drink lots of water to cool off. Did you know that cows need to drink almost a bathtub full of water every day?

---

Reptiles are cold-blooded animals. The body temperature of cold-blooded animals changes with the outside temperature. They become hot when it is hot outside and cold when it is cold outside. But cold-blooded animals must also keep a constant temperature for their bodies to work right.
Cold-blooded animals do not use energy from their bodies to stay warm or cool. Instead, they use things around them. Crocodiles stay in water or mud to stay cool on hot days. If they need to warm up on cooler days, they lie in the sun.
Warm-blooded animals can live in many different places, but cold-blooded animals can only live in certain places. Cold-blooded animals do not need to eat as much as warm-blooded animals. Most crocodiles only eat once a week, but they can live for months without eating!

option_2: how scientists group animals
option_3: why animals need water
option_4: when animals eat food

option_2_explanation: Great job! You found the main idea by seeing how "scientists put animals into groups" throughout the story. The passage explains grouping animals into mammals and reptiles.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story only mentions water once. The main idea is about "scientists put animals into groups" like mammals and reptiles.
option_4_explanation: Close! The story mentions eating a little, but it's mostly about how "scientists put animals into groups." Look for what the whole story talks about most.

Mammals are warm-blooded animals. When warm-blooded animals are in a cold place, they use energy from food to keep their bodies warm. Some warm-blooded animals shiver to stay warm. When they shiver, their bodies make heat.
When warm-blooded animals are somewhere hot, their bodies work differently to cool off. Some warm-blooded animals, like people, sweat to stay cool. Dogs pant to stay cool. Other warm-blooded animals drink lots of water to cool off. Did you know that cows need to drink almost a bathtub full of water every day?

---

Reptiles are cold-blooded animals. The body temperature of cold-blooded animals changes with the outside temperature. They become hot when it is hot outside and cold when it is cold outside. But cold-blooded animals must also keep a constant temperature for their bodies to work right.
Cold-blooded animals do not use energy from their bodies to stay warm or cool. Instead, they use things around them. Crocodiles stay in water or mud to stay cool on hot days. If they need to warm up on cooler days, they lie in the sun.
Warm-blooded animals can live in many different places, but cold-blooded animals can only live in certain places. Cold-blooded animals do not need to eat as much as warm-blooded animals. Most crocodiles only eat once a week, but they can live for months without eating!

Warm-blooded animals can live in many different places, but cold-blooded animals can only live in certain places. Cold-blooded animals do not need to eat as much as warm-blooded animals. Most crocodiles only eat once a week, but they can live for months without eating!

question: PART A: According to the passage, how do warm-blooded animals keep a steady body temperature, unlike cold-blooded animals?
option_1: They use energy from food to make heat inside their bodies.
option_2: They grow new fur or feathers whenever they feel cold.
option_3: They drink a lot more water than cold-blooded animals.
option_4: They must lie in the sun or shade to warm up or cool down.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found the right answer about how warm-blooded animals stay warm. The story says they "use energy from food" to make heat inside their bodies.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say animals grow new fur when cold. It says warm-blooded animals "use energy from food" to make heat inside their bodies.

option_1: Because their temperature fluctuates with surroundings, they need environments that stay within safe temperature ranges
option_2: Because they cannot move quickly, they must stay in places where predators are rare
option_3: Because they eat less often, they can only survive where food is scarce
option_4: Because they prefer water habitats, they must live near rivers, lakes, or oceans
option_1_explanation: Exactly! When an animal's "body temperature changes with the outside temperature," it needs places that aren't too hot or cold. If it gets too extreme, their body can't work right!
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't talk about how fast animals move or predators. It's really about how cold-blooded animals need safe temperatures to live.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story says cold-blooded animals eat less, which would help them live in MORE places. The real reason is about temperature, not food.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story mentions crocodiles use water to cool off, not that all cold-blooded animals need water. It's about finding places with safe temperatures!

passage_text:
Warm-Blooded and Cold-Blooded Animals
    
    
        Hello! Rattenborough here again! In the last chapter, you learned how scientists put living things into groups called kingdoms. You learned about animals and plants. You also learned that animals get put into smaller groups too.
Today, you will learn more about the animal kingdom. There are many kinds of animals that are different from each other. Scientists look at these differences to put animals into groups.

---

Many animals like cats, mice, rats, cows, elephants, tigers, and even people belong to a group called mammals. So you and I are mammals! All mammals have hair, but some have more hair than others. You have to get very close to an elephant to see its hair, but it is still a mammal. Another thing about mammals is that they give birth to live babies. Mammal babies start breathing, moving, and looking for food right when they are born. Mammal mothers make milk to feed their babies. This is a very important thing that all mammals do.
Do you think a crocodile is a mammal? The answer is no! Here's why. Crocodiles have hard scales, not hair or fur. Crocodiles lay eggs and baby crocodiles come out of those eggs. A baby crocodile does not get milk from its mother. Its first meal might be a bug. Later, it will eat bigger animals.
Crocodiles belong to a different group of animals called reptiles. Snakes, lizards, and turtles are reptiles too.

---

Scientists also put animals into groups based on how they control their body temperature. All animals need to keep a constant temperature inside their bodies. This means the temperature stays the same. If an animal gets too hot or too cold, its body will not work right. The animal may get sick or even die.
Mammals are warm-blooded animals. When warm-blooded animals are in a cold place, they use energy from food to keep their bodies warm. Some warm-blooded animals shiver to stay warm. When they shiver, their bodies make heat.
When warm-blooded animals are somewhere hot, their bodies work differently to cool off. Some warm-blooded animals, like people, sweat to stay cool. Dogs pant to stay cool. Other warm-blooded animals drink lots of water to cool off. Did you know that cows need to drink almost a bathtub full of water every day?

---

Reptiles are cold-blooded animals. The body temperature of cold-blooded animals changes with the outside temperature. They become hot when it is hot outside and cold when it is cold outside. But cold-blooded animals must also keep a constant temperature for their bodies to work right.
Cold-blooded animals do not use energy from their bodies to stay warm or cool. Instead, they use things around them. Crocodiles stay in water or mud to stay cool on hot days. If they need to warm up on cooler days, they lie in the sun.
Warm-blooded animals can live in many different places, but cold-blooded animals can only live in certain places. Cold-blooded animals do not need to eat as much as warm-blooded animals. Most crocodiles only eat once a week, but they can live for months without eating!
question: According to paragraph 5, what does the statement 'Cold-blooded animals do not use energy from their bodies to stay warm or cool' reveal about their survival strategy?
option_1: They have developed physical features that eliminate the need for temperature regulation entirely
option_2: They depend on behavioral adaptations like choosing sunny or shady spots rather than internal processes
option_3: They must hibernate during extreme weather because they cannot control their temperature
option_4: They evolve more quickly than warm-blooded animals to match their environment
option_1_explanation: Good try! But the story says cold-blooded animals still need to keep the right temperature. They just use sun and water instead of body energy to stay warm or cool.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The story says they "use things around them" like sun and water. Cold-blooded animals move to different places to control their temperature instead of using body energy.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't talk about hibernation. It says cold-blooded animals move to sunny spots or water to stay the right temperature.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story talks about how animals control temperature right now. It doesn't say anything about how fast they change over time.
differentiation_notes: Targets interpretation of survival strategy statement in paragraph 5 - differs from reference Part B by focusing on strategy rather than habitat implications
homogeneity_check: all choices describe survival strategies or adaptations
specificity_check: all explain survival mechanisms
length_check: A:13 words, B:14 words, C:13 words, D:12 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: eliminating regulation need, behavioral adaptations, hibernation, and rapid evolution are distinct strategies
single_correct_check: only B correctly identifies the external behavioral approach described
diversity_check: analyzes strategy statement in paragraph 5 - different analytical focus (survival strategy vs. habitat range) from reference Part B

passage_text:
Vertebrate or Invertebrate?
    
    
        Hello, Rattenborough here again! Scientists who study animals put them into different groups. They look at many things about animals. Some scientists check if animals have hair or scales on their skin. They see if animals have live babies or lay eggs. They also check if mothers feed milk to their babies. Scientists want to know if animals are warm-blooded or cold-blooded too.
One very important thing scientists study is the animal's backbone. Animals that have a backbone are called vertebrates. Humans are vertebrates too! Put your hand on the back of your neck. Do you feel a bump? Now rub your hand up and down the middle of your back. You can feel bumpy bones that go in a row down your back. These bones go from your neck to your waist. This is your backbone. Another name for backbone is spine.

---

Your backbone or spine does an important job. It wraps around and keeps safe a special part of your body called the spinal cord. The spinal cord is like a bundle of nerves. Messages travel up and down your spinal cord from your brain to other parts of your body. This is how your brain tells the rest of your body what to do.
Many other animals are vertebrates too. All mammals, reptiles, fish, and birds have a backbone. This means they are all vertebrates. They have some type of spinal cord as well. Animals with a backbone come in many different shapes and sizes. Apes, rhinos, horses, rabbits, and bats are all mammals and vertebrates. Lizards, turtles, snakes, and crocodiles are reptiles and vertebrates. Big sharks and tiny goldfish are also vertebrates. Small hummingbirds and large eagles are vertebrates too.

---

But many animals do not have a backbone at all. Animals without a backbone are called invertebrates. Insects are the biggest group in the animal kingdom. Insects are also the biggest group of invertebrates. Insects include flies, wasps, beetles, cockroaches, ladybugs, and butterflies. Other kinds of invertebrates include earthworms and spiders.
Some very interesting invertebrates live in the sea. Lobsters, shrimp, and crabs do not have a backbone. The giant octopus is an invertebrate as well. Have you ever seen a jellyfish or a starfish? They are also invertebrates. All of these animals do not have a backbone or spinal cord.
question: Why do scientists study whether animals have a backbone?
option_1: Scientists use backbones to group animals into categories.
option_2: Scientists want to see which animals are the biggest.
option_3: Scientists need to count how many bones animals have.
option_4: Scientists want to know how fast animals can run.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found the key detail that scientists "put them into different groups" based on backbones. The story shows scientists sort animals this way!
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story talks about grouping animals, not finding the biggest ones. Scientists study backbones to sort animals into groups.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but scientists don't count bones in this story. They use backbones to put animals into different groups like vertebrates.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story never mentions how fast animals run. Scientists study backbones to sort animals into groups, not for speed.

passage_text:
Vertebrate or Invertebrate?
    
    
        Hello, Rattenborough here again! Scientists who study animals put them into different groups. They look at many things about animals. Some scientists check if animals have hair or scales on their skin. They see if animals have live babies or lay eggs. They also check if mothers feed milk to their babies. Scientists want to know if animals are warm-blooded or cold-blooded too.
One very important thing scientists study is the animal's backbone. Animals that have a backbone are called vertebrates. Humans are vertebrates too! Put your hand on the back of your neck. Do you feel a bump? Now rub your hand up and down the middle of your back. You can feel bumpy bones that go in a row down your back. These bones go from your neck to your waist. This is your backbone. Another name for backbone is spine.

---

Your backbone or spine does an important job. It wraps around and keeps safe a special part of your body called the spinal cord. The spinal cord is like a bundle of nerves. Messages travel up and down your spinal cord from your brain to other parts of your body. This is how your brain tells the rest of your body what to do.
Many other animals are vertebrates too. All mammals, reptiles, fish, and birds have a backbone. This means they are all vertebrates. They have some type of spinal cord as well. Animals with a backbone come in many different shapes and sizes. Apes, rhinos, horses, rabbits, and bats are all mammals and vertebrates. Lizards, turtles, snakes, and crocodiles are reptiles and vertebrates. Big sharks and tiny goldfish are also vertebrates. Small hummingbirds and large eagles are vertebrates too.

---

But many animals do not have a backbone at all. Animals without a backbone are called invertebrates. Insects are the biggest group in the animal kingdom. Insects are also the biggest group of invertebrates. Insects include flies, wasps, beetles, cockroaches, ladybugs, and butterflies. Other kinds of invertebrates include earthworms and spiders.
Some very interesting invertebrates live in the sea. Lobsters, shrimp, and crabs do not have a backbone. The giant octopus is an invertebrate as well. Have you ever seen a jellyfish or a starfish? They are also invertebrates. All of these animals do not have a backbone or spinal cord.
question: Why does the author have readers touch their neck and back in the second paragraph?
option_1: to help readers understand what a backbone feels like
option_2: to describe the difference between vertebrates and invertebrates
option_3: to show how scientists study animal groups
option_4: to explain how the spinal cord sends messages
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found that the author wants readers to "feel bumpy bones" so they know what a backbone is like. The touching helps you understand your own spine!
option_2_explanation: Good try! The author isn't comparing different animals here. The "put your hand" part just helps you feel what your backbone is like.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the touching isn't about how scientists work. When it says "you can feel bumpy bones," it's helping you understand your backbone.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The touching part comes before the spinal cord explanation. It's there to help you feel what a backbone is like first.

question: Based on the second paragraph, what would most likely happen if a person's spinal cord was damaged?
option_1: The person's backbone would break into pieces.
option_2: The person's brain could not tell the body what to do.
option_3: Scientists could not classify the person as a vertebrate.
option_4: The person would no longer have bumpy bones in their back.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The backbone and spinal cord are different things. The backbone protects the spinal cord, so hurting the spinal cord wouldn't break the backbone.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The passage says "your brain tells the rest of your body what to do" through the spinal cord. If the spinal cord is hurt, the brain can't send messages to the body.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! A person would still be a vertebrate because they still have a backbone. Having a backbone makes you a vertebrate, not having a working spinal cord.
option_4_explanation: Close! The bumpy bones are the backbone, not the spinal cord. The spinal cord is inside the backbone, so the bumpy bones would still be there.

Animals with a backbone come in many different shapes and sizes. Apes, rhinos, horses, rabbits, and bats are all mammals and vertebrates. Lizards, turtles, snakes, and crocodiles are reptiles and vertebrates. Big sharks and tiny goldfish are also vertebrates. Small hummingbirds and large eagles are vertebrates too.

---

But many animals do not have a backbone at all. Animals without a backbone are called invertebrates. Insects are the biggest group in the animal kingdom. Insects are also the biggest group of invertebrates. Insects include flies, wasps, beetles, cockroaches, ladybugs, and butterflies. Other kinds of invertebrates include earthworms and spiders.
Some very interesting invertebrates live in the sea. Lobsters, shrimp, and crabs do not have a backbone. The giant octopus is an invertebrate as well. Have you ever seen a jellyfish or a starfish? They are also invertebrates. All of these animals do not have a backbone or spinal cord.

passage_text:
Fish
    
    
        Hello! Rattenborough here again! You have learned that scientists study animals. They put animals into different groups like mammals and reptiles. Today you will learn about another group of animals - fish.
Fish are aquatic animals. This means they live their whole lives underwater. Most fish are cold-blooded. Their body temperature changes when the water gets warmer or cooler. Fish are also animals with backbones. They are the largest group of animals with backbones on Earth. Since most of our planet is covered with water, it makes sense that fish are everywhere.
Fish lay their eggs underwater. They also eat and sleep under the water. Fish do not sleep the same way people do. Fish cannot close their eyes because they do not have eyelids. When they sleep, they float around or find a safe place to hide and rest.

---

Like all animals, fish need to breathe oxygen. But fish do not have lungs like people do. They cannot breathe air like we can. Instead, fish have special body parts called gills right behind their heads. The gills take oxygen out of the water so fish can breathe. But gills only work in water. They cannot take oxygen from the air. A fish will die very quickly if it is taken out of water.
Fish have scales that cover their skin. Scales are small, round, and smooth pieces. They protect the fish's skin and help them move easily through water. Fish also use different fins on their bodies and their tails to swim. The fins help them glide through water and change direction quickly.

---

Most fish live in salt water because most water on Earth is salty. Fish that live in the warm ocean are very colorful. They look like an artist painted beautiful patterns on their bodies. Many fish also live in fresh water like streams, rivers, lakes, and ponds.
Some fish travel together in groups called a school. One type of fish that travels in a school is salmon. Salmon live in both salt water and fresh water. Some salmon are born in fresh water streams and rivers. After about one year, they swim to the ocean where they live for one to five years. Then they migrate back to the exact same stream where they were born. They lay their eggs and start the life cycle all over again.

---

Salmon do not use a map to find their way back home. Most scientists think they use their strong sense of smell to find their way. They swim upstream against the river's flow. Sometimes they swim hundreds of miles. They jump over waterfalls and rocks to get back to the same stream where they were born. They work very hard to reach their home to lay their eggs.
Along the way, they hope that grizzly bears or people fishing will not catch them first. Salmon happen to be one of the tastiest fish of all!
question: Which fact about salmon is clear from the information in the passage?
option_1: Salmon are the only fish that travel in schools.
option_2: Salmon live only in fresh water their whole lives.
option_3: Salmon return to the same stream where they were born.
option_4: Salmon use maps to find their way home.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says salmon is "one type" of fish that travels together, which means other fish do it too. The passage tells us salmon "migrate back to the exact same stream where they were born."
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says salmon live in "both salt water and fresh water," so they don't stay in fresh water their whole lives. They "migrate back to the exact same stream where they were born."
option_3_explanation: You got it! The passage clearly states "they migrate back to the exact same stream where they were born." You found the right detail about what salmon do!
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story says salmon "do not use a map" but use their nose to smell their way. The passage tells us they "migrate back to the exact same stream where they were born."

passage_text:
Fish
    
    
        Hello! Rattenborough here again! You have learned that scientists study animals. They put animals into different groups like mammals and reptiles. Today you will learn about another group of animals - fish.
Fish are aquatic animals. This means they live their whole lives underwater. Most fish are cold-blooded. Their body temperature changes when the water gets warmer or cooler. Fish are also animals with backbones. They are the largest group of animals with backbones on Earth. Since most of our planet is covered with water, it makes sense that fish are everywhere.
Fish lay their eggs underwater. They also eat and sleep under the water. Fish do not sleep the same way people do. Fish cannot close their eyes because they do not have eyelids. When they sleep, they float around or find a safe place to hide and rest.

---

Like all animals, fish need to breathe oxygen. But fish do not have lungs like people do. They cannot breathe air like we can. Instead, fish have special body parts called gills right behind their heads. The gills take oxygen out of the water so fish can breathe. But gills only work in water. They cannot take oxygen from the air. A fish will die very quickly if it is taken out of water.
Fish have scales that cover their skin. Scales are small, round, and smooth pieces. They protect the fish's skin and help them move easily through water. Fish also use different fins on their bodies and their tails to swim. The fins help them glide through water and change direction quickly.

---

Most fish live in salt water because most water on Earth is salty. Fish that live in the warm ocean are very colorful. They look like an artist painted beautiful patterns on their bodies. Many fish also live in fresh water like streams, rivers, lakes, and ponds.
Some fish travel together in groups called a school. One type of fish that travels in a school is salmon. Salmon live in both salt water and fresh water. Some salmon are born in fresh water streams and rivers. After about one year, they swim to the ocean where they live for one to five years. Then they migrate back to the exact same stream where they were born. They lay their eggs and start the life cycle all over again.

---

Salmon do not use a map to find their way back home. Most scientists think they use their strong sense of smell to find their way. They swim upstream against the river's flow. Sometimes they swim hundreds of miles. They jump over waterfalls and rocks to get back to the same stream where they were born. They work very hard to reach their home to lay their eggs.
Along the way, they hope that grizzly bears or people fishing will not catch them first. Salmon happen to be one of the tastiest fish of all!

option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't mention water keeping their eyes open. Fish can't close their eyes because they don't have eyelids.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't talk about fish eyes moving during sleep. It says they can't close their eyes because they don't have eyelids.

Fish are aquatic animals. This means they live their whole lives underwater. Most fish are cold-blooded. Their body temperature changes when the water gets warmer or cooler. Fish are also animals with backbones. They are the largest group of animals with backbones on Earth. Since most of our planet is covered with water, it makes sense that fish are everywhere.
Fish lay their eggs underwater. They also eat and sleep under the water. Fish do not sleep the same way people do. Fish cannot close their eyes because they do not have eyelids. When they sleep, they float around or find a safe place to hide and rest.

---

Like all animals, fish need to breathe oxygen. But fish do not have lungs like people do. They cannot breathe air like we can. Instead, fish have special body parts called gills right behind their heads. The gills take oxygen out of the water so fish can breathe. But gills only work in water. They cannot take oxygen from the air. A fish will die very quickly if it is taken out of water.
Fish have scales that cover their skin. Scales are small, round, and smooth pieces. They protect the fish's skin and help them move easily through water. Fish also use different fins on their bodies and their tails to swim. The fins help them glide through water and change direction quickly.

---

Most fish live in salt water because most water on Earth is salty. Fish that live in the warm ocean are very colorful. They look like an artist painted beautiful patterns on their bodies. Many fish also live in fresh water like streams, rivers, lakes, and ponds.
Some fish travel together in groups called a school. One type of fish that travels in a school is salmon. Salmon live in both salt water and fresh water. Some salmon are born in fresh water streams and rivers. After about one year, they swim to the ocean where they live for one to five years. Then they migrate back to the exact same stream where they were born. They lay their eggs and start the life cycle all over again.

---

Salmon do not use a map to find their way back home. Most scientists think they use their strong sense of smell to find their way. They swim upstream against the river's flow. Sometimes they swim hundreds of miles. They jump over waterfalls and rocks to get back to the same stream where they were born. They work very hard to reach their home to lay their eggs.
Along the way, they hope that grizzly bears or people fishing will not catch them first. Salmon happen to be one of the tastiest fish of all!
question: Which step occurs after salmon swim to the ocean?
option_1: They are born in fresh water streams
option_2: They form groups called schools
option_3: They develop their sense of smell
option_4: They migrate back to lay their eggs
option_1_explanation: Good try! That's where salmon are born, but the question asks what happens after they swim to the ocean. The story says "Then they migrate back" to lay eggs.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! Schools are mentioned, but that's not what salmon do after living in the ocean. The story says they "migrate back" to where they were born to lay eggs.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but salmon already have their sense of smell - they don't develop it later. The story says "Then they migrate back" to lay their eggs.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You found the right order of events. The story says "Then they migrate back" to lay their eggs after living in the ocean.

They cannot take oxygen from the air. A fish will die very quickly if it is taken out of water.
Fish have scales that cover their skin. Scales are small, round, and smooth pieces. They protect the fish's skin and help them move easily through water. Fish also use different fins on their bodies and their tails to swim. The fins help them glide through water and change direction quickly.

---

Most fish live in salt water because most water on Earth is salty. Fish that live in the warm ocean are very colorful. They look like an artist painted beautiful patterns on their bodies. Many fish also live in fresh water like streams, rivers, lakes, and ponds.
Some fish travel together in groups called a school. One type of fish that travels in a school is salmon. Salmon live in both salt water and fresh water. Some salmon are born in fresh water streams and rivers. After about one year, they swim to the ocean where they live for one to five years. Then they migrate back to the exact same stream where they were born. They lay their eggs and start the life cycle all over again.

---

Salmon do not use a map to find their way back home. Most scientists think they use their strong sense of smell to find their way. They swim upstream against the river's flow. Sometimes they swim hundreds of miles. They jump over waterfalls and rocks to get back to the same stream where they were born. They work very hard to reach their home to lay their eggs.
Along the way, they hope that grizzly bears or people fishing will not catch them first. Salmon happen to be one of the tastiest fish of all!

passage_text:
Amphibians
    
    
        Hello again from your friend Rattenborough! Today we will learn about a special group of animals. These animals can live in water and on land. This group is called amphibians. The word amphibian comes from Latin words that mean "both sides of life."
There are three main types of amphibians. Frogs and toads make up the biggest group. Salamanders and newts are another group. The third group looks like big snakes because they have no legs. We don't know much about this last group because they live underground most of the time.

---

Let's look at how an American toad grows and changes during its life. Like all amphibians, toads are cold-blooded. This means their body temperature changes when the weather gets hot or cold. When winter comes, some amphibians hibernate. Some toads dig deep holes in the ground. Other amphibians like frogs bury themselves in mud at the bottom of ponds. When amphibians hibernate, they can survive for many months without eating or moving. They use fat stored in their bodies to stay alive.
A toad's life starts as one of thousands of soft, slimy eggs. The mother toad lays her eggs near the shore of a pond, lake, or quiet stream. But most of these eggs will never hatch. Fish and other animals will eat them first. If the eggs move away from shore into bright sunlight, they will dry out and die.

---

Only a few hundred eggs out of thousands will hatch into tadpoles. A tadpole is very fragile and small. Its young body has mainly a mouth, a tail, and gills. Tadpoles live in water and use gills to breathe underwater, just like fish do.
After some time, tadpoles start swimming around and eating tiny water plants. Tadpoles like to stay together in groups, similar to schools of fish. But this makes it easier for other animals to catch and eat them. Most tadpoles become food for fish and other creatures.
If a tadpole can survive for about a month, amazing changes begin to happen. Skin starts to grow over its gills. After six to nine weeks, the tadpole grows little legs. As its body changes, it starts to look less like a water animal and more like a land animal.

---

After a few months, the young toad leaves the water and moves onto land. It might still have a small tail, but that will disappear soon. By this time, its gills have changed into lungs. Now the toad breathes air instead of getting oxygen from water like fish do. Soon it becomes a full-grown adult toad that hops around on land. Adult amphibians are carnivores. This means they eat insects, small reptiles, and even mice.
Adult toads are still great swimmers and can swim underwater. But they cannot use their lungs to breathe underwater anymore. Instead, their thin, wet skin can absorb oxygen right from the water around them.
Amphibians are truly amazing animals. They are the only animals that have both gills and lungs during their lives. As adults, they live on land but still lay their eggs in water. Now you can see why the Latin meaning of amphibian makes perfect sense!
question: According to the passage, the changes in a tadpole's body help it
option_1: swim faster
option_2: hide better
option_3: eat more
option_4: live on land

option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story never mentions hiding better. It says tadpoles change so "the young toad leaves the water" to live on land.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't say tadpoles change to eat more food. It shows they change so they can "live on land" as adults.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You found the right answer by reading that "the young toad leaves the water and moves onto land." The changes help toads live on land!

There are three main types of amphibians. Frogs and toads make up the biggest group. Salamanders and newts are another group. The third group looks like big snakes because they have no legs. We don't know much about this last group because they live underground most of the time.

---

Let's look at how an American toad grows and changes during its life. Like all amphibians, toads are cold-blooded. This means their body temperature changes when the weather gets hot or cold. When winter comes, some amphibians hibernate. Some toads dig deep holes in the ground. Other amphibians like frogs bury themselves in mud at the bottom of ponds. When amphibians hibernate, they can survive for many months without eating or moving. They use fat stored in their bodies to stay alive.
A toad's life starts as one of thousands of soft, slimy eggs. The mother toad lays her eggs near the shore of a pond, lake, or quiet stream. But most of these eggs will never hatch. Fish and other animals will eat them first. If the eggs move away from shore into bright sunlight, they will dry out and die.

---

Only a few hundred eggs out of thousands will hatch into tadpoles. A tadpole is very fragile and small. Its young body has mainly a mouth, a tail, and gills. Tadpoles live in water and use gills to breathe underwater, just like fish do.
After some time, tadpoles start swimming around and eating tiny water plants. Tadpoles like to stay together in groups, similar to schools of fish. But this makes it easier for other animals to catch and eat them. Most tadpoles become food for fish and other creatures.
If a tadpole can survive for about a month, amazing changes begin to happen. Skin starts to grow over its gills. After six to nine weeks, the tadpole grows little legs. As its body changes, it starts to look less like a water animal and more like a land animal.

---

After a few months, the young toad leaves the water and moves onto land. It might still have a small tail, but that will disappear soon. By this time, its gills have changed into lungs. Now the toad breathes air instead of getting oxygen from water like fish do. Soon it becomes a full-grown adult toad that hops around on land. Adult amphibians are carnivores. This means they eat insects, small reptiles, and even mice.
Adult toads are still great swimmers and can swim underwater. But they cannot use their lungs to breathe underwater anymore. Instead, their thin, wet skin can absorb oxygen right from the water around them.
Amphibians are truly amazing animals. They are the only animals that have both gills and lungs during their lives. As adults, they live on land but still lay their eggs in water. Now you can see why the Latin meaning of amphibian makes perfect sense!
question: How does hibernating help amphibians survive winter?
option_1: It allows them to live without food for months
option_2: It helps them grow legs faster
option_3: It makes their eggs hatch sooner
option_4: It lets them swim in frozen water
option_1_explanation: Great job! The story says amphibians can "survive for many months without eating" during hibernation. They use stored fat to stay alive all winter.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story talks about growing legs, but that's not about hibernation. Hibernation helps animals survive winter, not grow faster.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but hibernation happens in winter when it's cold. The story says eggs are laid near ponds in warmer times, not during winter.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! When amphibians hibernate, they dig holes or hide in mud and don't move. The story says they survive "without moving," not by swimming.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 2 about hibernation survival mechanism - differs from reference which asks about tadpole body changes enabling land life

question: What must happen before a tadpole can grow legs?
option_1: It must eat tiny water plants
option_2: It must survive for about a month
option_3: It must leave the water completely
option_4: It must lose all of its gills
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story does say tadpoles eat plants, but that's not what must happen first. The tadpole needs to "survive for about a month" before legs can start growing.

option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but that's backwards! Tadpoles grow legs while still in the water. They leave the water after their legs have already grown.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story shows legs grow first, then skin grows over the gills later. Tadpoles don't need to lose all their gills before getting legs.

Now the toad breathes air instead of getting oxygen from water like fish do. Soon it becomes a full-grown adult toad that hops around on land. Adult amphibians are carnivores. This means they eat insects, small reptiles, and even mice.
Adult toads are still great swimmers and can swim underwater. But they cannot use their lungs to breathe underwater anymore. Instead, their thin, wet skin can absorb oxygen right from the water around them.
Amphibians are truly amazing animals. They are the only animals that have both gills and lungs during their lives. As adults, they live on land but still lay their eggs in water. Now you can see why the Latin meaning of amphibian makes perfect sense!

passage_text:
Amphibians
    
    
        Hello again from your friend Rattenborough! Today we will learn about a special group of animals. These animals can live in water and on land. This group is called amphibians. The word amphibian comes from Latin words that mean "both sides of life."
There are three main types of amphibians. Frogs and toads make up the biggest group. Salamanders and newts are another group. The third group looks like big snakes because they have no legs. We don't know much about this last group because they live underground most of the time.

---

Let's look at how an American toad grows and changes during its life. Like all amphibians, toads are cold-blooded. This means their body temperature changes when the weather gets hot or cold. When winter comes, some amphibians hibernate. Some toads dig deep holes in the ground. Other amphibians like frogs bury themselves in mud at the bottom of ponds. When amphibians hibernate, they can survive for many months without eating or moving. They use fat stored in their bodies to stay alive.
A toad's life starts as one of thousands of soft, slimy eggs. The mother toad lays her eggs near the shore of a pond, lake, or quiet stream. But most of these eggs will never hatch. Fish and other animals will eat them first. If the eggs move away from shore into bright sunlight, they will dry out and die.

---

Only a few hundred eggs out of thousands will hatch into tadpoles. A tadpole is very fragile and small. Its young body has mainly a mouth, a tail, and gills. Tadpoles live in water and use gills to breathe underwater, just like fish do.
After some time, tadpoles start swimming around and eating tiny water plants. Tadpoles like to stay together in groups, similar to schools of fish. But this makes it easier for other animals to catch and eat them. Most tadpoles become food for fish and other creatures.
If a tadpole can survive for about a month, amazing changes begin to happen. Skin starts to grow over its gills. After six to nine weeks, the tadpole grows little legs. As its body changes, it starts to look less like a water animal and more like a land animal.

---

After a few months, the young toad leaves the water and moves onto land. It might still have a small tail, but that will disappear soon. By this time, its gills have changed into lungs. Now the toad breathes air instead of getting oxygen from water like fish do. Soon it becomes a full-grown adult toad that hops around on land. Adult amphibians are carnivores. This means they eat insects, small reptiles, and even mice.
Adult toads are still great swimmers and can swim underwater. But they cannot use their lungs to breathe underwater anymore. Instead, their thin, wet skin can absorb oxygen right from the water around them.
Amphibians are truly amazing animals. They are the only animals that have both gills and lungs during their lives. As adults, they live on land but still lay their eggs in water. Now you can see why the Latin meaning of amphibian makes perfect sense!

option_1: It clarifies why toads lay thousands of eggs
option_2: It explains the reason amphibians must hibernate
option_3: It shows how tadpoles develop gills and lungs
option_4: It describes what adult amphibians eat as carnivores
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says toads lay thousands of eggs because most get eaten by fish, not because they're cold-blooded. Being cold-blooded is about body temperature, not eggs.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The story says cold-blooded means "body temperature changes when the weather gets hot or cold." That's why amphibians must hibernate when winter comes!
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't connect gills and lungs to being cold-blooded. All tadpoles grow gills and lungs as they change into adults.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Being cold-blooded is about body temperature changing with the weather. The story doesn't talk about what adult amphibians eat in this part.
